author: iricigor
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Invoke-Item /tmp
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Throw a PowerShell error (i.e. no default handler is available or similar).

The issue is not folder specific, i.e. it fails on any folder. It is tested on PS 6.1.0-preview.2 

The issue seems to be related to #4252 and #4262, but this is more to address proper error handling than to actually implement the functionality.

Actual behavior
---------------

It throws different errors from the underlying system.
On Debian Stretch, it throws full 9 line xdg-open error stack.
![screenshot_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15923171/39673167-52fe39f8-5137-11e8-840e-4ae95eb774d2.png)

On Debian subsystem on Windows 10, it throws 'No such file or directory' whereas folder exists. If a folder is really not existing, it throws 'Cannot find path'
![screenshot_2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15923171/39673171-67f01c0a-5137-11e8-8aff-1225d471288b.png)


Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iricigor does this repro with 6.2-preview.4?  I tried this on macOS and it opened the /tmp folder just fine

comments.author: iricigor
comments.body:
Hi @SteveL-MSFT, I cannot reproduce the problem on Ubuntu 16.04 VM with PowerShell 6.1.2, neither with 6.2.0-preview.3.  :relieved:

However, on Windows Subsystem Linux (WSL) problem persists on both distributions I have, Ubuntu 16.04 and Debian 9, with both latest official and preview versions of PowerShell. In all 4 cases, the error is the same as the above. Though, I am not even sure if that's supported scenario (pwsh running under Linux, but with Windows GUI).

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: There have been issues running with WSL that don't repro with the Linux kernel.  I would probably suggest opening this in https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL

title: Invoke-Item /tmp fails on Debian with strange errors
